awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: IP Programmable Rights Units On Blockchains
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to revolutionize global participation in the intellectual property ecosystem.  This company's innovation signifies a paradigm shift in how society comprehends and manages intellectual property, paving the way for increased value creation and democratizing a system historically marred by complexity, cost, and opacity. Leveraging the inherent characteristics of blockchains—decentralization, peer-to-peer dynamics, transparency, and cryptographic verifiability it is possible to establish an open, efficient, and inclusive system for intellectual property licensing and transactions. This project’s innovation will break down barriers, both legal and economic, for creators across diverse fields, including artists, writers, filmmakers, and scientific and business innovators.  Technical understanding of cost-efficient blockchain based platforms, today one of the biggest barriers to large scale blockchain based use cases, will be enhanced due to the efforts of this project.  Additionally, enhanced technical understanding of composable legal representations and models while maintaining business meaning will be achieved.  The global intellectual property rights market is projected to be $21B by 2029 and the blockchain token/NFT market is projected to be $211B by 2030.  This disruptive enabling technology has significant commercial potential.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to demonstrate the ability to deconstruct intensely complex prose based legal constructs representing intellectual property rights into “programmable rights units” and operate these units on any blockchain in a compute efficient and cost efficient manner. The objectives are twofold. First, the project will accurately deconstruct prose-based legal documents into composable IP licensing elements, “programmable rights units,” and represent them in non-lossy semantic meanings.  These deconstructed units must be capable of execution on blockchains in a commercially viable way. Second, the project will demonstrate the ability to implement composable programmable rights in a blockchain-agnostic form.  This objective is crucial for commercial success as the proliferation of blockchains will continue, thus, supporting many blockchains is required for a broad addressable market. These objectives will require usage of modeling techniques, linguistic pattern analysis (natural language processing and otherwise), technical architectural cost impact analysis as well as algorithmic evaluation of leading edge technologies such as zero knowledge proofs and cryptographically independently verifiable artifacts and identities. The anticipated results will be a proven, blockchain agonistic platform that accurately represents the semantic meaning of complex IP rights business models that can be automatically interacted with for executing commercial transactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to revolutionize intellectual property (IP) licensing and commercialization by addressing the inefficiencies, high costs, and complexity of current systems.  By modernizing and reengineering these systems, the initiative fosters healthy competition and fuels U.S. innovation, strengthening the nation’s ability to lead in a global knowledge-driven economy.  The team sought to create a decentralized, transparent, and automated IP licensing platform based on programmable rights units (PRUs) and advanced technologies like blockchain, cryptography, and natural language processing.

Intellectual Merit

Major Achievements:

  1. Development of the IP3 Mobilization Framework™: This framework provides a foundation for digitizing and systematizing IP licensing as a dynamic supply chain. It redefines IP licensing from static agreements to orchestrated, verifiable workflows, supporting a decentralized and cryptographically secure ecosystem.

  2. Advances in Licensing Transactions: The project demonstrated the feasibility of schema-based digital licensing agreements that can operate across blockchain platforms. By iterating on technical architectures, the team shifted from a purely blockchain-centric model to a decentralized data network anchored on blockchain for cryptographic verifiability.

  3. Technical Breakthroughs:

    • Introduced ontology for core copyright grants (e.g., performance, reproduction) as the foundation for licensing models.

    • Decentralized privacy based architectures (e.g. use of Merkle trees and Zero Knowledge Proofs)  incorporating selective visibility and data sovereignty.

  4. Architectural Evolution: Through iterative research, the team developed cost-effective architectures for data-intensive licensing applications. The final target architecture supports schema validation, cryptographic auditing, and global identifier resolution, overcoming blockchain limitations.

Broader Impacts

Broader  Access to IP Commercialization: The project focused on broadening  access to IP licensing, making it efficient  and accessible to a broader range of entrepreneurs,  creators and business innovators. These advancements are essential for U.S. businesses to innovate, thrive, and maintain global competitiveness. Supporting equitable access to IP ensures a steady influx of diverse ideas, which are critical for fostering leadership in global innovation.

Applications Beyond IP: The project's findings extend beyond IP licensing, offering frameworks that can be applied to broader legal and technological domains. For example:

  • AI Integration: The semantically rich IP licensing model has potential applications in legal AI, improving accuracy and contextual understanding in automated legal reasoning.

  • Interdisciplinary Impact: Graph databases, RDF modeling, and JSON-LD approaches developed in this project can transform legal research and compliance management in other domains.

Impact on Society: The work has the potential to foster innovation across a very broad range of industries - ranging from music and art to biotechnology and high tech chip manufacturing. By reducing costs and complexity in IP transactions, the project promotes fair compensation and equitable participation for innovators, aligning with societal goals for innovation and inclusive economic growth.  These advancements are critical to ensuring that U.S. businesses can lead the way in technological and creative advancements, securing their position in an increasingly competitive global economy.

Educational Contributions: The project emphasized practical IP education, offering resources and mentorship through initiatives like the IP Guardians community. These efforts aim to bridge the knowledge gap and equip creators, students, and entrepreneurs with the tools to navigate and thrive in the IP economy.

This project represents a paradigm shift in how IP is managed, setting the stage for a future where IP licensing is more  efficient, transparent and a powerful driver of innovation and economic growth. By addressing both technical and societal challenges, it has redefined the possibilities for broader participation in the global knowledge economy, ensuring that creators, businesses, and industries alike can thrive in the digital age while maintaining a competitive edge on the world stage.


Last Modified: 01/28/2025
Modified by: Nicole Bryan
